Mientras tanto, los republicanos del Senado quieren reducir esto a $600 y exigen rescates corporativos.

También hemos exigido fondos para escuelas, hospitales y transporte público y los republicanos lo han tratado como un "factor decisivo".

Déjame aclarar algo.
Los demócratas han exigido:
- cheques de $1,200
- $600 para el desempleo
- Beneficios retroactivos

Eso no es solo una declaración, incluso la presidenta Pelosi está a favor de los beneficios retroactivos.

Tengo una gran solución para los republicanos que de repente están preocupados por el gasto público después de años de regalos corruptos.

Revoquemos la estafa tributaria GOP del '17 de $2 billones para financiar propuestas que ayudan a la clase trabajadora.

¡Y sas! ✅

"Te podemos dar un cheque de estímulo o desempleo, pero no las dos cosas", dicen los republicanos... los mismos que quieren proteger a las corporaciones contra acusaciones por abuso laboral, ofrecerle recortes de impuestos a los ricos, subsidios a sus "amigos" y más...

Estoy cansada de estas personas que apoyan, ignoran y ponen excusas por su comportamiento abusivo y luego de repente actúan como los bebés más mimados del mundo.

La gente tiene hambre y esto es lo que te enoja. Use esa energía para respaldar los cheques y beneficios x desempleo.

The absence of federal aid to states and localities is a threat to law enforcement budgets right now. State & local spending on public safety fell from 2010-2012 as those governments faced severe budget crises, and the same could happen again without federal support.

From 2008 to 2013, state and local governments cut their investments in programs to support children, and the same is likely to occur now in the absence of new federal support.
https://www.urban.org/urban-wire/great-recessions-lessons-state-and-local-aids-importance-combating-economic-downturn-and-supporting-children
Without federal support, they will also have to make damaging cuts to long-term investments that benefit us all, including K-12 education, law enforcement, and anti-poverty programs.

Beyond jobs, state & local gov'ts are at the forefront of combating the pandemic & poverty. They are funding testing sites, running food banks & supporting businesses w/ emergency assistance. With their funds from the CARES Act used up, they will have to pull back these efforts.

Research published in the NYT also finds that of the 40 cities facing revenue declines in FY 21 of over 4%, 17 are in states with 2 Democratic Senators, 16 are in states with 2 Republican Senators, and 7 are in states with Senators from both parties. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/17/upshot/pandemic-recession-cities-fiscal-shortfall.html

This job loss is not a blue state or red state issue, but an American issue. Since February, government employment has fallen by 46k in New York and 28k in New Jersey, but also by 49k in Texas and 42k in Florida.

Since February, state and local governments have cut over 1.3 million jobs as the pandemic has caused their revenues to fall steeply. This accounts for almost 15% of the jobs that have been lost and still not recovered since the pandemic hit.
https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/02/danger-sign-state-local-government-job-losses-grow-as-congress-stalls-on-relief-425546

During the Great Recession and its aftermath, a lack of support for state and local governments cost over 700k jobs and was an important factor in our slow recovery. I worry that we are making this same mistake today. https://www.taxpolicycenter.org/publications/state-and-local-governments-economic-recoveries-recovery-different

As we rapidly approach the holidays, I will keep fighting to make sure that neither the House nor the Senate head home until a bipartisan, bicameral bill is sent to the President’s desk and signed into law. 

Central Virginians have waited far too long for progress. 7/7
In this current moment – when millions of Americans are facing hunger, eviction, or the effects of a job loss, Congress cannot delay in passing a relief package. 6/7
They refused to hammer out their differences and recognize the severity of the crisis at hand. 5/7

Early in this pandemic, Congress responded to the COVID-19 crisis as a united, bipartisan front – but as a dire, painful need for aid persisted throughout the country, lawmakers in both parties abandoned that spirit. 4/7

Americans deserve better than their elected officials using federal employees, govt operations, and the security of our borders, airways, & country as bargaining tools – particularly when both parties should agree on the obvious & long-overdue need for COVID-19 relief. 3/7
In just a few days, Congress will once again need to vote to maintain the very functioning of our government. 2/7

Tonight’s vote is just one more example of a broken pattern of moving from one impending budgetary disaster to another. 

Congress repeatedly refuses to respond to fast-approaching funding deadlines, even though it has months to prepare and plan for these moments. 1/7 https://twitter.com/nbc12/status/1340076150807285762 QT @NBC12 BREAKING NEWS: The House passed the temporary funding bill by a 320-60 vote as frustrated lawmakers headed for a weekend session. https://www.nbc12.com/2020/12/18/shutdown-deadline-looms-over-covid-stimulus-checks-relief-talks/

This rule is key to protecting individual liberty. Laws granting legal benefits only to the few are prohibited, and oppressive laws are deterred because they can’t be made to apply only to those who are disfavored by voters or legislators—the law must equally burden everyone.

Equality before the law, as described by F.A. Hayek, goes beyond the Supreme Court’s current equal protection doctrine. It demands that the laws be applied equally to all, and it prohibits laws that make arbitrary distinctions to benefit or harm particular individuals or groups.

Today, I introduced a simple amendment to the Constitution: “Equality before the law shall be guaranteed by the United States and the several States.”

This amendment serves to more directly incorporate the concept of the Rule of Law into the Constitution.

The President’s failure to acknowledge the threat of the coronavirus and his refusal to use the power of the presidency to fight it will weigh down the U.S. economy for years to come.

That will be President Trump’s economic legacy.

#ERPResponse | http://bit.ly/Dem-Response-2020-ERP

And despite the fact that the share of Americans reporting symptoms of depressive and/or anxiety disorder has tripled in the past year, the President has ignored their illness and turned a blind eye to the suffering of millions of Americans.

The closure of child care centers and decreased supply of affordable child care during the pandemic has forced parents, disproportionately women, to work less or drop out of the labor force, yet the President has taken inadequate action to help them.
Inadequate paid sick leave during a pandemic can force Americans to go to work sick and risk infecting others, yet the President weakened sick leave provisions in coronavirus relief legislation.

Chapter four looks at how the Trump administration missed multiple opportunities to support workers and families in the wake of COVID-19 by ignoring major challenges with #PaidSickLeave, #ChildCare and #MentalHealth.

The working poor, immigrants, Black Americans, Hispanic Americans and Native Americans have been hit especially hard by the pandemic; they are more likely to contract COVID-19 or suffer extreme economic hardship as a result of the coronavirus recession.

Chapter three looks at inequality, and how the Trump administration’s failed response to COVID-19 has led to widespread suffering concentrated among the most vulnerable—the working poor, immigrants, Black, Hispanic and Native Americans and others. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Epios37XUAITXss.jpg

However, this does not reflect the fact that since February more than 5 million Americans have given up looking for work and have left the labor force. If they were counted as unemployed, the unemployment rate would be approximately three percentage points higher.

In recent months, leading economic indicators have improved from abysmal to mediocre. However, the economy is far weaker than the numbers suggest.

For example, the unemployment rate in November was 6.7 percent—two percentage points higher than when the President took office.

Chapter two focuses on the President's failure to use economic policy to mitigate the suffering caused by the coronavirus recession.

For months he blocked efforts to extend unemployment benefits, threatening to leave millions of families without income just after Christmas.

Chapter one of our response focuses on Trump’s record on the economy.

Trump inherited a strong economy from Pres. Obama. With the 2017 tax cuts, a harmful trade war and an unmaterialized “blue-collar boom,” the President’s record was unspectacular even before COVID-19. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EpioQwPW8AEDCxK.jpg
